Jagadish,

Welcome to the wonderful world of JUnit.

There are many useful =
websites for the JUnit user, but perhaps the two
main ones are http://www.j=
unit.org/ and http://www.google.com/. The
JUnit site maintains a lot of use=
ful information and links to other
resources. Many of the articles there ar=
e directed towards the
beginner and will help you greatly as you learn abou=
t JUnit. Google is
useful when there's something you need, but don't know w=
hat it is.
Just type a description in, press enter and see how much help it=
 can
be. I've found quite a few useful things that way. Another tip with
Go=
ogle is to search on the specific error message that you have, often
you'll=
 find forum discussions about that exact error, with a good
chance of a sol=
ution being given as well.

As you learn and start having questions, you wi=
ll also find the JUnit
FAQ very helpful. The questions that it answers real=
ly are the
frequent ones that most of us had asked or wondered about and Mi=
ke
Clark does a wonderful job of collating it. Here is a link:

http://juni=
t.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm

When you are ready to start asking more =
questions on the JUnit mailing
list, please consider following all of the a=
dvice in Eric Raymond's
very helpful document: "How to ask questions the sm=
art way", available
at his website. Here is a link:

http://www.catb.org/~e=
sr/faqs/smart-questions.html

As far as books are concerned, I recommend Pr=
agmatic Unit Testing by
Hunt and Thomas for beginners. JUnit recipes by Rai=
nsberger is good
once you're past the basics. There are other good books ou=
t there, but
these are my recommendations.

I hope that this helps.

Simon
=

www.simonpeter.com
